elements.content: Two novel heptanuclear lanthanide clusters of the dicubane-like type [Ln7(μ3-OH)8]13+ (Ln = Ho (1), Yb (2)) were obtained via hydrothermal reaction, and as building blocks, they were formally assembled into porous three-dimensional networks through the linkage of 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate (1,4-NDA), forming first examples of porous lanthanide polymers with 1,4-NDA, [Ln7(μ3-OH)8(1,4-NDA)6(OH)0.5(Ac)0.5(H2O)7]·4H2O (Ln = Ho, Yb). The coordinating water molecules and lattice water molecules are enclathrated in the cavities.
elements.clean_text: Two novel heptanuclear lanthanide clusters of the dicubane-like type [Ln7(μ3-OH)8]13+ (Ln = Ho (1), Yb (2)) were obtained via hydrothermal reaction, and as building blocks, they were formally assembled into porous three-dimensional networks through the linkage of 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate (1,4-NDA), forming first examples of porous lanthanide polymers with 1,4-NDA, [Ln7(μ3-OH)8(1,4-NDA)6(OH)0.5(Ac)0.5(H2O)7]⋅4H2O (Ln = Ho, Yb). The coordinating water molecules and lattice water molecules are enclathrated in the cavities.

elements.content: Two novel heptanuclear lanthanide clusters of the dicubane-like type [Ln7(μ3-OH)8]13+ (Ln = Ho (1), Yb (2)) were obtained via hydrothermal reaction, and as building blocks, they were formally assembled into porous three-dimensional networks through the linkage of 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate (1,4-NDA), forming first examples of porous lanthanide polymers with 1,4-NDA.
elements.clean_text: Two novel heptanuclear lanthanide clusters of the dicubane-like type [Ln7(μ3-OH)8]13+ (Ln = Ho (1), Yb (2)) were obtained via hydrothermal reaction, and as building blocks, they were formally assembled into porous three-dimensional networks through the linkage of 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate (1,4-NDA), forming first examples of porous lanthanide polymers with 1,4-NDA.

elements.content: High-nuclearity clusters are of great interest due to their novel structural characteristics and potential applications in magnetic, optical, electronic, and catalytic processes for their size-dependent physical properties. The synthesis of the high-nuclearity clusters is still a great challenge. A common synthetic strategy is to control the hydrolysis of the salts of metal ions in the aid of supporting ligands. Hydrophilic groups such as oxo, hydroxo, and carboxylate bridge the metal ion to make up a cluster core, while hydrophobic groups take up the positions in the periphery, preventing the core from further aggregation. In contrast to the well-established cluster chemistry of transition metals, the analogous chemistry of lanthanides is less developed. Thus far, tetra-, penta-, hexa-, octa-, nona-, dodeca-, tetradeca-, and pentadecanuclear8b lanthanide clusters have been obtained. But work about heptanuclear lanthanide clusters has not been reported yet. Gao2 and Zheng8e et al. selected α-amino acid with dicarboxylate (l-aspartic acid and l-glutamic acid) as supporting ligand to bridge individual units containing the cubane-like [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ cluster, and reported the first assembly of a discrete lanthanide cluster into a three-dimensional network via conventional solution reaction. In the present case, we obtained the first examples of heptanuclear lanthanide hydroxo clusters [Ln7(μ3-OH)8]13+ via hydrothermal reaction, and we use it as a building block to form a 3-D framework through the linkage of a linear dicarboxylate 1,4-NDA.
elements.clean_text: High-nuclearity clusters are of great interest due to their novel structural characteristics and potential applications in magnetic, optical, electronic, and catalytic processes for their size-dependent physical properties. The synthesis of the high-nuclearity clusters is still a great challenge. A common synthetic strategy is to control the hydrolysis of the salts of metal ions in the aid of supporting ligands. Hydrophilic groups such as oxo, hydroxo, and carboxylate bridge the metal ion to make up a cluster core, while hydrophobic groups take up the positions in the periphery, preventing the core from further aggregation. In contrast to the well-established cluster chemistry of transition metals, the analogous chemistry of lanthanides is less developed. Thus far, tetra-, penta-, hexa-, octa-, nona-, dodeca-, tetradeca-, and pentadecanuclear8b lanthanide clusters have been obtained. But work about heptanuclear lanthanide clusters has not been reported yet. Gao2 and Zheng8e et al. selected α-amino acid with dicarboxylate (l-aspartic acid and l-glutamic acid) as supporting ligand to bridge individual units containing the cubane-like [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ cluster, and reported the first assembly of a discrete lanthanide cluster into a three-dimensional network via conventional solution reaction. In the present case, we obtained the first examples of heptanuclear lanthanide hydroxo clusters [Ln7(μ3-OH)8]13+ via hydrothermal reaction, and we use it as a building block to form a 3-D framework through the linkage of a linear dicarboxylate 1,4-NDA.

elements.content: A solution of NaAc·3H2O (0.04 g,0.3 mmol), YbCl3·6H2O (0.039 g, 0.1 mmol), H2O (10 mL), and aqueous NaOH (0.6 mL, 0.39 mmol) was stirred and precipitates were formed, then 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.033 g, 0.15 mmol) was added. The mixture was sealed in a 25-mL stainless steel reactor with Teflon liner and heated at 120 °C for 72 h. Yellow crystals of 2 were obtained in a yield of 0.018 g (44%). With the same method, crystals of 1 were prepared in a yield of 0.02 g (50%). 1 and 2 are isomorphous. Therefore, only the structure of 2 was described in detail. The asymmetrical unit of 2 consists of a neutral heptanuclear [Yb7(μ3-OH)8(1,4-NDA)6(OH)0.5(Ac)0.5(H2O)7] (Figure ) and four lattice water molecules. In the asymmetrical unit, seven Yb3+ ions are all eight-coordinate, but with markedly different coordination environments (Table ), and the supporting ligand 1,4-NDA adopts three coordination modes:  bis(bridging bidentate) (I), bis(chelating bidentate) (II), and bridging bidentate and chelating bidentate (III) in a ratio of 2:1:3. The terminal hydroxo and terminal acetate both coordinate to the Yb3+ ions in monodentate mode. The large neutral heptanuclear section has a heptanuclear [Yb7(μ3-OH)8]13+ core in which the metal skeleton can be regarded as two vertex-sharing tetrahedral tetranuclear units assembled via a metal ion Yb1. Yb1−Yb4 compose one tetrahedron with Yb···Yb distance in the range between 3.65 and 3.79 Å, and Yb1, Yb5−Yb7 make up the other with Yb···Yb distance in the range between 3.64 and 3.82 Å. Each triangular face of the tetrahedron is capped by one μ3-OH group, so that the heptanuclear core is surrounded by eight μ3-OH groups. The average distance of the μ3-OH groups to the triangular metal faces is ca. 0.90 Å. In addition, besides the bridging of the μ3-OH groups, seven 1,4-NDA ligands bridge Yb1 and Yb2, Yb2 and Yb3, Yb2 and Yb4, Yb1 and Yb5, Yb5 and Yb6, Yb5 and Yb7, Yb6 and Yb7, respectively with one of their carboxylate groups. Alternatively, the [Yb7(μ3-OH)8]13+ core displays a distorted vertex-sharing dicubane-like structure (Figure ) in which the μ3-OH groups are also considered as vertices of the polyhedron.
elements.clean_text: A solution of NaAc⋅3H2O (0.04 g,0.3 mmol), YbCl3⋅6H2O (0.039 g, 0.1 mmol), H2O (10 mL), and aqueous NaOH (0.6 mL, 0.39 mmol) was stirred and precipitates were formed, then 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (0.033 g, 0.15 mmol) was added. The mixture was sealed in a 25-mL stainless steel reactor with Teflon liner and heated at 120 °C for 72 h.  Yellow crystals of 2  were obtained in a yield of 0.018 g (44%). With the same method, crystals of 1  were prepared in a yield of 0.02 g (50%). 1 and 2 are isomorphous. Therefore, only the structure of 2 was described in detail. The asymmetrical unit of 2 consists of a neutral heptanuclear [Yb7(μ3-OH)8(1,4-NDA)6(OH)0.5(Ac)0.5(H2O)7] (Figure ) and four lattice water molecules. In the asymmetrical unit, seven Yb3+ ions are all eight-coordinate, but with markedly different coordination environments (Table ), and the supporting ligand 1,4-NDA adopts three coordination modes: bis(bridging bidentate) (I), bis(chelating bidentate) (II), and bridging bidentate and chelating bidentate (III) in a ratio of 2:1:3. The terminal hydroxo and terminal acetate both coordinate to the Yb3+ ions in monodentate mode. The large neutral heptanuclear section has a heptanuclear [Yb7(μ3-OH)8]13+ core in which the metal skeleton can be regarded as two vertex-sharing tetrahedral tetranuclear units assembled via a metal ion Yb1. Yb1-Yb4 compose one tetrahedron with Yb⋅⋅⋅Yb distance in the range between 3.65 and 3.79 Å, and Yb1, Yb5-Yb7 make up the other with Yb⋅⋅⋅Yb distance in the range between 3.64 and 3.82 Å. Each triangular face of the tetrahedron is capped by one μ3-OH group, so that the heptanuclear core is surrounded by eight μ3-OH groups. The average distance of the μ3-OH groups to the triangular metal faces is ca. 0.90 Å. In addition, besides the bridging of the μ3-OH groups, seven 1,4-NDA ligands bridge Yb1 and Yb2, Yb2 and Yb3, Yb2 and Yb4, Yb1 and Yb5, Yb5 and Yb6, Yb5 and Yb7, Yb6 and Yb7, respectively with one of their carboxylate groups. Alternatively, the [Yb7(μ3-OH)8]13+ core displays a distorted vertex-sharing dicubane-like structure (Figure ) in which the μ3-OH groups are also considered as vertices of the polyhedron.

elements.content: Coordination environment of the heptanuclear core in2:  (a) Yb1−Yb4; (b) Yb1, Yb5−Yb7.

elements.content:
The Coordination Environments of Yb3+ Ions in the Asymmetrical Unit of 2

no. of carboxylate oxygen atoms no. of μ3-OH I II III no. of H2O no. of OH or Ac Yb1 6 2 Yb2 3 2 1 2 Yb3 3 1 2 1 1 Yb4 3 2 3 Yb5 3 2 1 2 Yb6 3 2 2 1 Yb7 3 1 3 1

The cubane-like tetranuclear [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ unit is a common structural motif in lanthanide oxo−hydroxo clusters as demonstrated by the present work and others. The reported tetranuclear [Dy4(μ3-OH)4(asp)3(H2O)8]2+, dodecanuclear [Er12(μ3-OH)16(I)2(μ3-Tyr)8(H2O)20]10+, and pentadecanuclear [Gd15(μ3-OH)20(μ5-Cl)(μ3-Tyr)10(OH) (μ2-H2O)5(H2O)19]13+  8b can all be regarded as being composed of one or more [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ units. It can be deduced that, for a cyclic core composed of n vertex-sharing [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ cubanes, the nuclear number is 3n (n ≥ 3), while for a chainlike core composed of n vertex-sharing [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ cubanes, the nuclear number is 3n + 1 (n ≥ 2).
elements.clean_text: The cubane-like tetranuclear [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ unit is a common structural motif in lanthanide oxo-hydroxo clusters as demonstrated by the present work and others. The reported tetranuclear [Dy4(μ3-OH)4(asp)3(H2O)8]2+, dodecanuclear [Er12(μ3-OH)16(I)2(μ3-Tyr)8(H2O)20]10+, and pentadecanuclear [Gd15(μ3-OH)20(μ5-Cl)(μ3-Tyr)10(OH) (μ2-H2O)5(H2O)19]13+             8b can all be regarded as being composed of one or more [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ units. It can be deduced that, for a cyclic core composed of n vertex-sharing [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ cubanes, the nuclear number is 3n (n ≥ 3), while for a chainlike core composed of n vertex-sharing [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ cubanes, the nuclear number is 3n + 1 (n ≥ 2).

elements.content: Each 1,4-NDA ligand contributes one carboxylate group for the coordination of one [Yb7(μ3-OH)8]13+ cluster while using the remaining one to coordinate an adjacent lanthanide cluster cube. Around every heptanuclear cluster, there are twelve 1,4-NDA ligands which orientate in three directions:  [110], [101], and [11̄0]. In every direction, there are four 1,4-NDA ligands linking three heptanuclear clusters. Thus every heptanuclear core is located in an octahedral center, surrounded by six other cores with the distance of the centers of the heptanuclear cores ranging from 12.7 to 15.6 Å. Every 2-connecting 1,4-NDA ligand links two heptanuclear cores. If every heptanuclear core is regarded as a point possessing a certain geometry, a 3-D open framework of α-Po-related topology can be constructed. And the 3-D open framework exhibits many cavities (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Each 1,4-NDA ligand contributes one carboxylate group for the coordination of one [Yb7(μ3-OH)8]13+ cluster while  using the remaining one to coordinate an adjacent lanthanide cluster cube. Around every heptanuclear cluster, there are twelve 1,4-NDA ligands which orientate in three directions: [110], [101], and [11̄0]. In every direction, there are four 1,4-NDA ligands linking three heptanuclear clusters. Thus every heptanuclear core is located in an octahedral center, surrounded by six other cores with the distance of the centers of the heptanuclear cores ranging from 12.7 to 15.6 Å. Every 2-connecting 1,4-NDA ligand links two heptanuclear cores. If every heptanuclear core is regarded as a point possessing a certain geometry, a 3-D open framework of α-Po-related topology can be constructed. And the 3-D open framework exhibits many cavities (Figure ).

elements.content: The 3-D open framework of2 showing the cavities. All hydrogen atoms and water molecules were omitted.
elements.clean_text: 3  The 3-D open framework of2 showing the cavities. All hydrogen atoms and water molecules were omitted.

elements.content:
Enclathrated in the cavities are coordinating water molecules and lattice water molecules which are hydrogen-bonded to the coordinating water molecules and coordinating carboxylate oxygen atoms.

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility of 2 was measured in the temperature range 2−300 K (Figure ). The magnetic susceptibility above 50 K obeys the Curie−Weiss law [χ = C/(T − θ)] with C = 17.7(2) cm3 K mol-1, and θ = −27.3(4) K. The C value is very close to the expected value of 17.99 cm3 K mol-1 for seven noninteracting Yb3+ free ions. The continuous decrease in χM T upon cooling should be mainly attributed to the crystal field splitting of a single Yb3+ ion.
elements.clean_text:
Enclathrated in the cavities are coordinating water molecules and lattice water molecules which are hydrogen-bonded to the coordinating water molecules and coordinating carboxylate oxygen atoms. 

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility of 2 was measured in the temperature range 2-300 K (Figure ). The magnetic susceptibility above 50 K obeys the Curie-Weiss law [χ = C/(T - θ)] with C = 17.7(2) cm3 K mol-1, and θ = -27.3(4) K. The C value is very close to the expected value of 17.99 cm3 K mol-1 for seven noninteracting Yb3+ free ions. The continuous decrease in χM T upon cooling should be mainly attributed to the crystal field splitting of a single Yb3+ ion.

elements.content: Plot of the temperature dependence of χM T (○) and χM -1 (□) for 2 (per [Yb]7 unit).
elements.clean_text: 4  Plot of the temperature dependence of χM T (○) and χM -1 (□) for 2 (per [Yb]7 unit).

elements.content: The thermal stability of 2 was investigated by thermogravimetric analysis. The first weight loss of 6.4% from 90 °C to 195 °C corresponds to the loss of seven coordinating water molecules and four lattice water molecules (calculated:  6.9%), leaving a framework of [Yb7(μ3-OH)8(1,4-NDA)6(OH)0.5(Ac)0.5]. The framework begins to decompose at 433 °C and ends at 675 °C with the residue Yb2O3 obtained.

The framework begins to decompose at 433 °C and ends at 675 °C with the residue Yb2O3 obtained.

metadata.title:
Synthesis and Characterization of Two Novel Lanthanide Coordination
Polymers with an Open Framework Based on an Unprecedented
[Ln7(μ3-OH)8]13+ Cluster
